prompt.preamble: We are testing a system for understanding people's fuzzy intuitions and preferences. In this activity, we're going to be looking at different strings of text and you'll be deciding if they look like they could be an email address or not. For example, most people would agree that "username@domain.com" looks like an email address, while "n12z5lFEN4" does not. However, the rules for what can be an email address can be very unusual, so what we're really interested in is your intuition on what an email address could look like. Tip: in an email such as username@cs.stanford.edu, "username" is called the local-part of the email, while "cs.stanford.edu" is the domain. Furthermore, "cs" is a subdomain, and "edu" is a top-level domain.
prompt.task_description: your intuition of what is or is not possible for an email address
prompt.final: In the final part of the study, you will give feedback on a test set of email addresses, which will enable us to see how well a chatbot reading your responses has learned your email preferences.
prompt.evaluation: Please indicate whether you think the following strings look like reasonably well-formatted email addresses or not: "yes" if they do, "no" if they don't.

conversation_history.message: Should the following be accepted? user@name@example.com

This email address shouldnt be used, there can only be 1 specified local-part so for this to function as an emil address you could use user@example.com OR name@example.com.  I believe that this email would fail to send.
Should the following be accepted? user@name_example.com

This email address looks correct, the user is the local part and name_example is the domain and @com is a valid top-level domain.  The underscore in the domain does make it look a litte unusual but I believe this looks like a vaid email address
Should the following be accepted? user.name@subdomain.example.com
This email address looks correct. user.name is a very common local-part of an email address, first.surname for example.  The subdomain looks correct as does the domain and top level domain.

evaluation_results.label: yes
evaluation_results.explanation: I have never seen a top-level domain "a" or any other single letter

evaluation_results.label: no
evaluation_results.explanation: the syntax is incorrect for the domain and top level domain

query_prompt.content:
Your task is to learn what rules a user believes to be a valid email address format must adhere to (e.g. for developing a regex format checker).

Come up with a potential edge case to learn as much information as you can about what their desired behavior should be under different circumstances.
Make sure the edge case addresses different aspects of the system than the edge cases that have already been considered.

An example edge case is: Should the following email be accepted? username@example.com

Current cases:
- [Q] -> [A]

Generate the most informative edge case that, when answered, will reveal the most about the desired behavior beyond what has already been queried for above. Generate the edge case in the following format, and nothing else: "Should the following be accepted? [edge case]"
